Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the high unemployment rates in right-to-work states are directly caused by their right-to-work status, without considering other factors that may contribute to unemployment.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or data to support the correlation between right-to-work status and high unemployment rates. It only mentions that six out of ten states with the highest unemployment rates are right-to-work states, but does not provide any further analysis or statistical evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert mentions that there is a question about causation vs. correlation, indicating that there may be other factors at play that contribute to the high unemployment rates in these states. This suggests that there could be alternative explanations for the observed correlation between right-to-work status and high unemployment rates.
